Eventually, everyone has pain.  I started my chronic pain journey at 17.  I am 41 yo now.  It has always felt very unfair.  But at this stage in my life, as the caregiver to my mother (stroke 65yo), and my grandmother (91yo dementia), I have realized that as we age, it comes to all of us.  At 91, my grandmother has lived a life free of any health problems, has never had chronic pain, and wouldn't know what a headache was like if she were hit in the head with a hammer.But, my grandfather died about 20 years ago, and she has never stopped grieving.  She has been in immense psychological pain for more 20 years.  She was also abused as a child, so has trauma from a life of abuse before that.  She has had pain daily for her whole life.My mother has had chronic pain her entire life from childhood.  Whether the form of pain is physical, emotional or psychological, none of us are safe from it.  Some people get to live longer without pain.  They get a longer period of their lives free of trauma, physical pain, or emotional pain- but eventually- the pain comes for them too. People like us, we had a shorter ride to chronic pain.  We didn't get as many years of freedom as we would have liked.But understand that you are not alone.  Every human on this big blue ball has pain.  Just like many of us have invisible illnesses, most every person in the world suffers from invisible pain.  You are not special, you are not unique, you are not alone.  Just because your friend group or family might not have a chronic illness, it does not mean they do not have pain.  It means they classify their pain differently.There is one advantage to living a life like ours- riding the early short bus to chronic pain.  Pain and survival build resilience.  We learn very early in our journey how to cope with grief, sadness, anger, and how to adapt quickly.  Those who ride the late bus to chronic pain have to develop these tools late in life, when it is more difficult to develop new coping skills.  They often never learn coping skills, and never move on with their lives.We learn how to adapt and change, because we have done it so many times before.  We become stronger everytime a doctor doesn't believe us.  We grow stronger everytime we drag ourselves out of bed for one more day of work when we can barely make it.  We grow stronger every day we survive what is sometimes a nightmare of life.  This strength of understanding how to navigate pain puts us years ahead of the people in our lives who haven't ridden the bus to chronic pain yet.  When the day comes that your friend who was always healthy and pain free finally takes that ride to chronic pain, they will look at you and wonder how you ever survived.  They will fall off the cliff into depression and grief.  Hopefully, you will be there to help pull them out and share the tools that you have learned.

It's definitely not the case that most prescription migraine medications have caffeine. Most prescriptions actually don't have it, caffeine is much more commonly found in OTC meds like excedrin. The only prescription med that does have caffeine is Fioricet, which isn't super popular and actually can be made without caffeine if you have access to a compounding pharmacy. Here is a list of common prescription migraine meds that don't have caffeine: triptans*, DHE/Trudhesa, diclofenac/Cambia, ketorolac/Toradol, Reyvow, Nurtec, Ubrelvy, muscle relaxers *triptans can be an issue if you have certain heart conditions, but there are 7 different types and as another commenter mentioned, one of them may be okay for you even if the others aren't. Of course discuss with your doctor first.

Dr. Dismissive strikes again. To give the doctor the benefit of the doubt, I will say that the binder may have been overwhelming. Doing that is great for doctors that will sit and take an hour with you, but those doctors are hard to find. Most have *maybe* 15 minutes for you and then they have to get the next patient in. It sucks, I know. So it’s possible that since your binder focused on eating habits and weight gain photos that the doctor got hung up on that and stopped listening. Doctors are always listening for something that will let them mark off something as easy. So if you talk about not sleeping, stress, fatigue, a job you hate, any mental illness, etc they’re going to say you’re just stressed or depressed. What you should do going forward before any doctor appointment is come up with three things that are bothering you and focus on those. Stick to specific symptoms and be short but blunt about it. For example, you could say something like “Over the past few years I’ve noticed that I’m getting what looks to be a “Buffalo hump” on my back and it’s making it difficult to lift my head. My PCP and I discussed the possibility of Cushings based on XYZ. Could we talk about what labs we could run to rule this in or out and what other things could cause my symptoms?”I would also message your doctor in your patient portal and say the same thing. I gave up trying to figure out the Canadian health care system and its private public options a while ago.People like to complain about these contracts, but there is no force of law behind them. They cant drag you in front of a judge for violations. Its really more of a statement of rules for that individual practice for prescribing controlled substances. Things like single pharmacy use. That makes life easier for the doctor should any issues arise or they need to contact your pharmacy. It shouldnt be an inconvenience for the patient. If you need to change call their office with the new pharmacy info. It takes about 30 seconds to change it.Drug testing is something we all have a beef with. Its not just to make sure that youre not taking anything that could affect overall treatment, but its also to make sure youre taking what youre prescribed, and in some cases, catch a metabolizing issue if one exists.In the US we have had a nation wide Rx database for I guess about 10 years. 3 states were holdouts, but I believe they all provide information now. Its not a bad thing, especially if you are in an accident and cant communicate with the Emergency doctors. In your case where youre getting the same type of drug from more than one doctor you can see the increased risk of an overdose, especially if the doctors arent all aware of what your taking from each of them. And theres a lot more than risk of an overdose. Some interactions can kill you with issues like serotonin syndrome. Tramadol and anti depressants can be a very big deal.These contracts also tell you about Rx refill procedures/hours, so with a contract, you shouldnt be caught short on medication, at least not on the doctors end. The pharmacy and insurance are different problems. I may have a sample opioid contract around if youre interested in seeing one, you can find template on line pretty easy. Theyre just the rules of the practice, there's even a little advice in them sometimes, like a police report will not get you a refill if youre ripped off. Keep your meds safe with the same care youd use to store a firearm. Lock boxes and safes are good ideas, even though they only keep honest people honest. If they steal your safe, you will probably have more important things to report being stolen. So its hard to say if its normal in Canada. Its pretty normal south of the border. And they present it in a way that drives these rules home, which is why its called contract rather than rules.
